text: So ‘30% more’ is more for an 85 year-old than a 20 year-old?

elements.text: So ‘30% more’ is more for an 85 year-old than a 20 year-old?

text: Well I'm not sure the "30%" more is known exactly enough at this point to say whether it's uniform across the age distribution - suppose it could be for 20 year olds we go from 0.01% to 0.013%, and for a 85 year old we go from 15% to 20%, but it might as well be any other impact (e.g. 0.01 to 0.1% for 20 year olds but no impact on 85 year olds)

elements.text: Well I'm not sure the "30%" more is known exactly enough at this point to say whether it's uniform across the age distribution - suppose it could be for 20 year olds we go from 0.01% to 0.013%, and for a 85 year old we go from 15% to 20%, but it might as well be any other impact (e.g. 0.01 to 0.1% for 20 year olds but no impact on 85 year olds)

text: I guess if the PM of a country that has led a botched response feels compelled to say this in a press brief, things are pretty bad.

elements.text: I guess if the PM of a country that has led a botched response feels compelled to say this in a press brief, things are pretty bad.

text: The death rate has an unknown denominator, it is conceivable that they can compute how much more deadly one strain is than the other by cancelling the denominators (if they can pin them down up to the same unknown constant)… just saying it is not per se a contradiction.
